Fig. 1 XRD patterns of Ni2P@C-T catalysts. Fig 1 Fig. 2 SEM images of Ni2P@C-500(a), Ni2P@C-600(b), Ni2P@C-700(c,e), Ni2P@C-800(d) and elemental mapping of Ni2P@C-700 (f-i). Fig 2 Fig. 3 TEM images, corresponding particle size distribution and HRTEM images of Ni2P@C-600 (a,d), Ni2P@C-700 (b,e) and Ni2P@C-800 (c,f). Fig 3 Fig. 4 XPS spectra of Ni2P@C-T catalysts. Fig 4 Fig. 5 NH3-TPD curves of Ni2P@C-T. Fig 5 Fig. 6 H2-TPD profiles of Ni2P@C-T. Fig 6 Fig. 7 Effect of solvent on the reductive amination of furfural Reaction conditions: Ni2P@C-700 50 mg, FF 10 mmol, N-butylamine 10 mmol, solvent 5 mL, H2 1 MPa, 150 oC, 4 h. Fig 7 Fig. 8 Optimized the reaction conditions over Ni2P@C-700 catalyst: (a)reaction temperature, (b) H2 pressure, (c) reaction time and (d) catalyst amount. Fig 8 Fig. 9 Recycle experiments of Ni2P@C-700 catalyst for the reductive amination of furfural Reaction conditions: Ni2P@C-700 40 mg, FF 10 mmol, N-butylamine 10 mmol, isopropanol 5 mL, H2 1.4 MPa, 170 oC, 2 h. Fig 9 Fig. 10 (a) XRD patterns and (b) TG curves of fresh and spent Ni2P@C-700 catalyst. Fig 10 Fig. 11 TEM images (a), HRTEM (b) and corresponding particle size distribution (c) of spent Ni2P@C-700. Fig 11 Scheme 1 A possible reaction path of the reductive amination of furfural. Scheme 1 Table 1 Acidity of Ni2P@C-T catalysts. Table 1 Catalyst Peak temperature / ºC NH3 uptake / mmol g−1 Ni2P@C-500 163.3 0.35 Ni2P@C-600 155.3 0.32 Ni2P@C-700 148.2 0.25 Ni2P@C-800 140.0 0.20 Table 2 Catalytic performance of Ni2P@C-T in the reductive amination of furfural. Table 2 Catalyst Conversion / % Selectivity / % N-butyl furfurylamine N-butyl furfurylimine Others Ni2P@C-500 100 58.5 26.2 15.3 Ni2P@C-600 100 68.9 19.5 11.6 Ni2P@C-700 100 73.0 18.1 8.9 Ni2P@C-800 100 15.8 79.9 4.3 Reaction conditions: catalyst 50 mg, FF 10 mmol, N-butylamine 10 mmol, methanol 5 mL, H2 1 MPa, 150 ℃, 4 h. Others: furfuryl alcohol, N-butyl tetrahydrofuranylamine and N-butyl bisfurfurylamine. The development of efficient non-noble metal catalysts for synthesizing amine derived from furfural has attracted attentions. Herein, a series of carbon-encapsulated nickel phosphide catalysts Ni2P@C-T were prepared using a facile pyrolysis strategy at different reduction temperatures by employing phytic acid as phosphorus and carbon source. The effects of reduction temperature on the particle size, exposed crystal faces and electronic property, as well as the catalytic performance of the Ni2P@C-T in the reductive amination of furfural were investigated. Higher Niδ+ content and appropriate acidity were beneficial to improve the catalytic performance of Ni2P@C-T, the selectivity of N-butyl furfurylamine over the Ni2P@C-700 catalyst reached 85.0 % at the furfural conversion of 100 % under optimal reaction conditions of 170 °C, 1.4 MPa H2 and 2 h. The stability experiment showed that the Ni2P@C-700 catalyst maintained high catalytic activity and selectivity after 6 cycles. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Carbon-encapsulated nickel phosphide furfural furfurylamine reductive amination Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Due to the exhaustion, quality decline and serious environmental pollution of fossil resources, the search for renewable alternative resources has attracted attention. As an inexpensive and abundant renewable carbon resource, biomass is the only substitution of fossil resources in the preparation of carbon-containing chemicals and fuels [1–4]. Furfural (FF), a platform molecule derived from biomass, can be translated into a variety of high-value fine chemicals, such as 2-methylfuran, furfuryl alcohol, valerolactone, pentanediol, functionalized aromatics and nitrogen-containing compounds [5–11]. Owing to comprehensive application in drugs, pesticides, polymer materials and organic synthesis, the preparation of nitrogenous compounds from furfural via the reductive amination has attracted attention [12–14]. Recently, many heterogeneous catalysts have been applied to the reductive amination of furfural, such as Ru [15–18], Rh [19], Pd [20,21], and Me/SiO2-SO3H (Me: Pt, Ir, Au) [22], etc. However, the limited scarcity and high cost prevented the widespread application of noble metal catalyst in the reductive amination. As an alternatives, non-precious metal catalysts have been extensively developed for furfural amination [23–25]. Zhuang et al. prepared a graphene-co-shelled cobalt nanoparticles, the generated sponge-like structures was favorable to the distribution of Co nanoparticles, furfurylamine was yielded to 86.2 % under 2 MPa H2 for 2 h when the introduced Co species acted as Lewis acid sites or electrophilic sites in the Co@C-600-EtOH catalyst [26], which could activate H2 in the hydrogenation process [27]. Over Co-embedded N-doped carbon nanocatalyst, the yield of N-[(furan-2-yl)methyl]formamide was 86 % when the reductive amination was performed for 12 h [28]. Employing 15 % Ni/MMT as a catalyst, due to the formation of Ni-Nx sites and the electronic interaction of N and Ni species on the N-doped carbon surface, the selectivity of furfurylamine reached 85 % with the 96 % conversion of furfural at the 15 bar H2 pressure for 7 h [29]. When Ni catalyst was supported by N-doped porous carbon, the selectivity of furfuryl amine reached 92.3 % at a >99 % conversion, but the H2 pressure was increased to 3 MPa [30]. The above results indicated that non-precious metals also performed a exceptional catalytic performance. However, severe reaction conditions such as high hydrogen pressures and long reaction time were typically required to attain sufficient selectivity and conversion. Therefore, developing highly efficient non-precious metal catalysts is still an urgent. Due to the special structure, transition metal phosphide exhibited catalytic properties similar to platinum and shown the excellent catalytic performance in hydrodeoxygenation, hydrodenitrogenation and hydrodesulfurization [31]. Recently, Sheng et al. employed single crystal cobalt phosphide nanorods (Co2P NRs) as catalysts for the reductive amination of furfural and the furfuramine was yielded to 90 % in an aqueous ammonia solution [32], it was due to the P-alloying strategy which increased the Co d-electron density around the Fermi level, facilitating the activation of H2 [33], but a reaction time of 10 h was required. Using Ni2P/SiO2 as a catalyst, N-alkyl-5-methyl-2-pyrrolidones was yielded to more than 94 % in the reductive amination of ethyl levulinate [34], it was attributed to the affluent weak Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, which were associated with P-OH groups and coordinatively unsaturated Ni sites [35], but the reaction temperature reached 170 °C. Consequently, an enhancement in the catalytic performance of Ni2P was essential under mild conditions for the reductive amination of furfural. To overcome the abovementioned issues, carbon-encapsulated Ni2P catalysts were prepared by using phytic acid and basic nickel carbonate as precursors through a facile pyrolysis strategy in this work. As a natural and environmentally friendly compound from plant sources, phytic acid with six phosphonic acid groups, could serves not only as P and C sources, but also as chelating agent to form strong interaction with metal ion, which was favorite to in-situ prepare the carbon encapsulated metal phosphide [36,37]. Encapsulating metal phosphides in carbon was not only beneficial for its dispersion [38], but also strengthened the electron transfer between Ni2P and carbon, which was benefited to improve the catalytic performance of Ni2P in the hydrogenation [39,40]. The influence of reduction temperature on the carbon encapsulated Ni2P catalyst was investigated and their catalytic performance was evaluated in the reductive amination of furfural. In the presence of carbon encapsulated Ni2P catalysts, the reaction parameters were also optimized. Under the optimal reaction conditions, carbon encapsulated Ni2P showed excellent catalytic performance and stability. The deactivation of carbon encapsulated Ni2P catalyst in the reductive amination was also investigated. Experimental section Materials Nickel carbonate basic was purchased from Tianjin Zhiyuan Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. From Tianjin Benchmark Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., phytic acid was obtained. Methanol was bought at Tianjin Kemio Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Furfural was purchased from Tianjin Fuchen Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Butyl amine was obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. All chemicals were used directly without further purification. Synthesis of catalyst Using the temperature programmed reduction method, the catalyst was obtained by a facile pyrolysis strategy. Phytic acid (1 mmol) and basic nickel carbonate (2 mmol) was mixed in a certain amount of distilled water and stirred for 10 min, and then heated 100 °C for 1 h. After that, the precursor was yielded when water was removed from the resultant mixture. Then, the precursor was ground and placed in a porcelain boat and pyrolyzed in a tubular reactor. The tubular reactor was heated to the set temperature with a rate of 2 °C/min under an H2 atmosphere, and kept for 3 h, a carbon encapsulated Ni2P catalyst Ni2P@C-T (T represents the reduction temperature, °C) was gotten. Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) from Bruker in Germany was applied to characterize the crystal structure of the catalyst. The data were collected in the 2θ ranges from 5 ° to 80 ° Scanning electron microscope (SEM) of TESCAN AMBER was employed to observe the morphology and distribution of elements. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis was carried on JEM-2100 transmission electron microscope. The sample was placed in an ethanol solution for ultrasonic dispersion, and then dropped on a copper web. ESCALAB 250 X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS) manufactured by Thermo Fisher Scientific was employed to determine the chemical valence state, type and relative content of elements on the surface of catalysts using Al K X-rays. The resolution function for this instrument has been determined to be 0.5 eV and the binding energy of all elements was corrected by the standard value of 284.6 eV of C 1 s, the corresponding spectra were fitted by a combination of Gaussian and Lorentzian functions with XPS PEAK software. Thermo Gravimetry (TG) analysis of catalysts before and after the reaction was carried out using Setline-STA synchronous thermal analyzer made by Setaram. The Ni2P@C-T was heated to 900 °C from room temperature with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in air. Ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD, Micromeritics, AutoChem II 2920) was employed to determine the acidity of Ni2P@C-T. Ni2P@C-T (0.2 g, 20–40 mesh) was put in a quartz tube and then heated to 500 °C with 15 °C/min for 1 h under Ar atmosphere, and then cooled to 100 °C under Ar. After flowing an NH3 over Ni2P@C-T for 30 min, the physically adsorbed NH3 was removed by the flowing Ar. Then the temperature of Ni2P@C-T was raised to 450 °C from 100 with a rate of 10 °C/min when the baseline was stabilized. The amount of desorbed NH3 corresponding to the TCD signal was titrated by labeled hydrochloric acid. For H2-TPD measurements, 10 % H2 in Ar (30 mL min−1) was switched into the system for 60 min to allow the adsorption on catalyst; then the pure argon was switched into the system for 30 min to blow away free adsorbate, and then the programmed temperature raising process was began from room temperature to 600 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1, simultaneously the TCD signal was recorded. Evaluating the catalytic performance of Ni2P@C-T in the reduction amination of furfural In a 50 mL stainless steel high pressure reactor equipped with magnetic agitator and temperature controller, the catalytic performance of Ni2P@C-T was tested in the reductive amination of furfural. Methanol (5 mL), FF (10 mmol), butylamine (10 mmol) and a certain amount of catalyst were put into the reactor. After sealing, flush the tank three times with hydrogen to remove air from the tank, and then fill the tank with hydrogen at a preset pressure. After the tightness was confirmed, the temperature of the reactor was increased to the desired reaction temperature with 10 °C/min and held it for a certain time. When the reaction was finished, the temperature of the reactor was dropped to room temperature. The reaction mixture was detected by the gas chromatography (GC 7900) with flame ionization detector (FID). In the catalyst recycle experiment, the catalyst was separated from the reaction system by centrifugation. The spent catalyst was washed and dried, and then was used in the next reaction. Results and discussion Characterization of Ni2P@C-T catalyst Powder X-ray diffraction was used to conduct phase qualitative analysis of Ni2P@C-T catalysts prepared at different reduction temperature, and the results are shown in Fig. 1 . The XRD patterns of Ni2P@C-500 showed diffraction peaks at 2θ = 40.7°, 44.6 °, 47.3 °, 54.1 °, 54.9 ° and 74.7 °, which were consistent with the characteristic diffraction peaks of Ni2P (PDF # 74–1385) (111), (201), (210), (300), (211) and (400) crystal planes. Simultaneously, the characteristic diffraction peaks corresponding to the crystal planes of Ni2P4O12 (PDF # 28–0708) (011), (-112) and (-222) were also observed at 2θ = 14.5°, 21.0 ° and 29.9 ° These results suggested Ni2P@C-500 was a mixture composed of Ni2P and Ni2P4O12, which could be attributed to the fact that the nickel phosphorus oxide in the precursor was not completely reduced and phosphatized at 500 °C. When the reduction temperature rose to 600 ℃ and above, the XRD patterns of Ni2P@C-T only showed the characteristic diffraction peaks of Ni2P (PDF # 74–1385) and no other diffraction peaks were found, indicating that pure Ni2P samples were prepared. Fig. 1 also showed the intensity of the corresponding characteristic diffraction peaks of Ni2P was enhanced with the increase of reduction temperature, suggesting that the particles of Ni2P gradually grew with promoting the reduction temperature and a largest Ni2P crystal was obtained at 800 °C. According to the (111) crystal plane (2θ = 40.7°), the particle size of Ni2P was calculated by using Scherrer equation. The particle size of Ni2P in Ni2P@C-T was increased from 27.2 to 33.0 and 64.0 nm when the reduction temperature was increased from 600 to 700 and 800 °C. In order to investigate the influences of reductive temperature on the morphology of the Ni2P@C-T, the SEM was used to observe its morphology (Fig. 2 ). From Fig. 2 (a–d), it can be seen that the Ni2P@C-T samples were irregular massive particles. Promoting the reduction temperature from 500 ℃ to 800 ℃, Ni2P showed a trend of aggregation. It was suggested that the higher reduction temperature was not conductive for the dispersion of Ni2P and consisted with the increase of diffraction peak intensity in XRD. At the same time, the elemental mapping of Ni2P@C-700 shown in Fig. 2 (f–i), and the results showed that Ni, P, C and O elements were uniformly distributed on the catalyst surface. To further observe the influence of reduction temperatures, TEM was performed to characterize Ni2P@C-T, and the results are shown in Fig. 3 . TEM images showed that the mean particle size of Ni2P was increased from 16.9 to 36.7 nm with rising the reduction temperature of the precursors from 600 to 700 °C, and the bigger particle of Ni2P and the more severe agglomeration were observed when the reduction temperature was set at 800 ℃. In high resolution transmission electron microscopy, Ni2P@C-600 showed the crystal face spacing of 0.202 nm, corresponding to the (201) crystal faces of Ni2P, Ni2P@C-700 displayed the crystal spacing of 0.221 nm and 0.507 nm, belonging to the (111) and (100) crystal faces of Ni2P, respectively, while Ni2P@C-800 exhibited the 0.221 nm crystal face spacing, corresponding to the (111) crystal face of Ni2P. The above results suggested the exposed crystal faces of Ni2P were influenced by the reduction temperature of the precursors. Due to the difference of coordinately-unsaturated active sites on the different crystal plane, Ni2P@C-T would show the different catalytic performance in the reductive amination of furfural [41]. Additive, in the Fig. 3(d–f), the carbon shell coating on the surface of Ni2P was observed and its thickness was decreased with rising the reduction temperature. It was reported that carbon layer was favorite to electron transfer, which would result in a higher catalytic activity [42]. To determine the surface compositions and chemical states of the Ni2P@C-T surface, XPS was applied to investigate the electronic properties, and the results are shown in Fig. 4 . The XPS survey spectra revealed that the catalysts consist of Ni, P, C and O elements (Fig. S1). For the Ni 2p of the catalysts prepared at 600, 700 and 800 °C, the peaks of the Ni 2p3/2 located at the electron binding energy of 853.3, 856.5 and 861.7 eV corresponded to the Niδ+ of the Ni-P compound, the Ni2+ and the satellite peaks, respectively [43–45]. The formation of Niδ+ species indicated an electron transfer from Ni to P in Ni2P and the existence of Ni2+ in Ni2P@C-T was due to the surface oxidation when it was exposed to air [46]. Because of the mixed phase of Ni2P and Ni2P4O12, Ni 2p binding energy of Ni2P@C-500 gave a positive shift comparing with Ni2P@C-T (T = 600,700 and 800 °C), which was caused by the strong P-O bond in P4O12 4− and the strong polarization of O2− [47]. It was suggested the electron density of Niδ+ in Ni2P@C-T (T=600,700 and 800 °C) was higher than that of Ni2P@C-500. For nickel phosphide catalyst, the Niδ+ was the active centers and the higher electron density of Ni was favorite to promoting the catalytic activity Ni2P@C-T in the hydrogenation [43,48–50]. Additively, the intensity of Niδ+ in Ni2P@C-T catalyst was affected by the reduction temperature (Fig. 4). The deconvolution results of spectra, as shown in Table S1, the Niδ+ content in Ni2P@C-T catalysts was increased from 34.6 % to 38.5 % when the reduction temperature was elevated from 600 °C to 700 °C, however, its content was dropped to 18.8 % when the reduction temperature was set at 800 °C. Two peaks were observed in the XPS spectrum of P 2p (Fig. 4). One peak at 130.1 eV in the low electron binding energy region corresponded to Pδ− [43,51], and other peak at 134.1 eV in the high electron binding energy region was attributed to P-O in phosphate and hypophosphate [52–54]. The presence of P-O might be owed to oxidation of the surface when Ni2P@C-T catalysts were exposed to air [55]. Comparing with other catalysts, the binding energy of P 2p in the Ni2P@C-500 catalyst exhibited the positive shift because the existence of the strong P-O bonds in P4O12 4− and the strong polarization of O2− [45]. The acidity of Ni2P@C-T was determined by NH3-TPD (Fig. 5 ). As shown in Fig. 5, Ni2P@C-T displayed a desorption peak of NH3 located around 150 °C, which was ascribed to Brønsted acid sites in Ni2P caused by the P-OH species [56]. It was also can be seen that the desorption temperature of NH3 gradually shifted to lower temperature with the increase of reduction temperature of the precursor, which means gradually weakening the surface acid strength of the prepared Ni2P@C-T. The desorbed ammonia was collected and titrated by labeled hydrochloric acid to determine the density of acid sites. The results in Table 1 exhibited the downward trend when the reduction temperature of the precursor was enhanced. The acid content of Ni2P@C-500 was 0.35 mmol/g and it decreased gradually to 0.20 mmol/g of Ni2P@C-800 with promoting the reduction temperature from 500 ℃ to 800 ℃. H2-TPD was an effective method to investigate the nature of the interaction between hydrogen species and catalyst surface, which disclosed the degree of H2 interaction over the active species and could be directly related to the desorption peaks. The H2-TPD measurements of Ni2P@C-T were performed and the profiles were shown in Fig. 6 . For Ni2P@C-T, two apparent peaks of hydrogen desorption were shown. The desorption peaks at low temperature (lower than 100 °C) was assigned to physical desorption of H2 and the others at high temperature (about 350 °C) was correspond to chemical desorption of H2 [57]. As the reduction temperature of the precursors increased, the H2 desorption amount tended to decrease, which indicated the dispersion of Ni2P was decreased with promoting the reductive temperature of precursors from 600 °C to 700 °C [58], and these results was consistent with the characterization of TEM and XRD. Although the results of XPS shown that the Niδ+ content of Ni2P@C-600 was fewer than that of Ni2P@C-700, the more H2 desorption amount was exhibited by Ni2P@C-600 due to the smaller critical size of Ni2P. The H2 desorption amount around 350 °C followed the sequence: Ni2P@C-600 > Ni2P@C-700 > Ni2P@C-800. Catalytic performance of Ni2P@C-T in the reductive amination of furfural Under the reaction conditions of 1.0 MPa H2, 150 °C and 4 h, the catalytic performance of Ni2P@C-T for the reductive amination of furfural with butylamine was evaluated in methanol (Table 2 ). The data in Table 2 suggested that furfural was converted completely in the reaction process, which was because the reaction between furfural and amine was rapidly [18]. Analyzing the reaction mixture by GC–MS (Fig. S2), N-butyl furfurylamine and N-butyl furfurylimine were founded as a target products and an intermediate, while furfuryl alcohol, N-butyl tetrahydrofuranylamine and N-butyl bisfurfurylamine were also detected as byproducts with using Ni2P@C-T as catalysts. As the comparing catalysts, Cu3P@C-700 and Co2P@C-700 were prepared (Fig. S3) and used as catalysts for the reductive amination of furfural. The results in Table S2 shown the N-butyl furfurylimine selectivity of 0 % and 1.2 % were obtained in the presence of Cu3P@C-700 and Co2P@C-700, it was indicated that the abilities for the catalytic hydrogenation of Cu3P@C-700 and Co2P@C-700 were lower than that of Ni2P@C-T (Table S2). Employing Ni2P@C-500 as a catalyst, the middle selectivity (58.5 %) of N-butyl furfurylamine was gained while the selectivity for N-butyl furfurylimine touched 26.2 %. It was due to the existence of Ni2P4O12 in this catalyst, which caused the shortage of the active component. The selectivity of 15.3 % for others was the highest, this is because the high density of acid sites and excessive acid strength of Ni2P@C-500 leaded to strong adsorption of the reactant, which was benefited to the generation of others via consecutive reactions [59]. The catalytic performance of Ni2P@C-T was improved when the reductive temperature of the precursors raised from 600 °C to 700 °C, and the maximum selectivity of N-butyl furfurylamine (73.0 %) was obtained over the Ni2P@C-700 catalyst. Further increasing the reduction temperature of the precursor to 800 oC, the selectivity for the N-butyl furfurylamine was significantly reduced to 15.8 % over the Ni2P@C-800. On the one side, a suitable carbon layer coated Ni2P particles in Ni2P@C-600 and Ni2P@C-700 protected Ni2P from oxidation, which caused the higher content of the active center Niδ+ for the hydrogenation. On the other hand, the appropriate acidity and the suitable concentrations of acid sites was benifited to the generation of the target product in the reductive amination [60,61]. Although the Ni2P@C-600 catalyst exhibited the less Niδ+, comparing with Ni2P@C-700, the amount of hydrogen desorbed is higher than that of the Ni2P@C-700 catalyst due to its small particle size, which is conducive to the hydrogenation reaction. However, the stronger acidity and the more acid sites of Ni2P@C-600 resulted in a selectivity of others higher than Ni2P@C-700[62]. As for Ni2P@C-800 catalyst, the minimum content of Niδ+ and the maximum particle size resulted in the least amount of hydrogen desorption on its surface, which can be attributed to the insufficient active sites exposed on the catalytic surface and suppressed the hydrogenation reaction of N-butyl furfurylimine. However, the lowest selectivity of others was shown due to it's the weaker acidity and the lower acid sites concentration. Therefore, the active center Niδ+ affected on the catalytic activity and the acidity influenced the catalytic selectivity when the Ni2P@C-T was employed as catalysts in the reductive amination of furfurfal. As the optimal catalyst, Ni2P@C-700 showed appropriate acid content and acid strength and the more amount of hydrogen desorbed, the best catalytic performance was obtained for reductive amination of furfural [62,63]. Optimized the reaction parameters To investigate the effects of solvent, the reductive amination of furfural was fulfilled in protic solvents and aprotic solvents over the Ni2P@C-700 catalyst, and the results showed in Fig. 7 . The selectivity of N-butyl furfurylamine obtained in a protic solvent was higher than that in an aprotic solvent. It was because the interaction between protic solvent and catalyst was stronger than that of aprotic solvent. As a resulting of this, the generation of byproducts was prevented and the selectivity of N-butyl furfurylamine was improved when alcohol was used as a solvent [64]. Among the investigated protic solvents, the selectivity of the target product was positively correlated with the solvent polarity, and methanol with the greater polarity gave the highest target product selectivity of 73.0 %. In order to optimize the reaction conditions, the influences of reaction temperature, H2 pressure, reaction time and catalyst amount were investigated respectively, the results are showed in Fig. 8 (a–d). It can be seen, the conversion of furfural was 100 % under the reaction conditions, it was due to the reaction between furfural and amine to generate N-butyl furfurylimine was rapidly. Therefore, increasing selectivity for butyl furfurylamine was the main objective of optimizing reaction conditions. Reaction temperature usually exhibited the great influence on the product selectivity in the reductive amination [30]. Therefore, with using 50 mg Ni2P@C-700 catalyst, the effects of reaction temperature for the furfural reductive amination were detected in mehanol at 1 MPa H2 for 4.0 h, and the results showed in Fig. 8(a). It can be seen that furfural could be fully converted during 110–190 ℃, the selectivity of N-butyl furfurylamine was positively correlated with the reaction temperature in the 110–170 ℃ range. Setting the reaction temperature at 110 ℃, the lowest selectivity of 15.6 % for N-butyl furfurylamine achieved. The selectivity of N-butyl furfurylamine arrived at 78.4 % when the reaction temperature rised to 170 ℃. However, the reductive amination of furfural was performed at 190 ℃, the selectivity of N-butyl furfurylamine reduced to 26.0 %, yet the selectivity of others (including N-butyl tetrahydrofuranylamine, N-butyl bisfurfurylamine) was more than 70 %, indicating the too high reaction temperature could accelerate the side reaction (such as hydrogenation of the furan ring and alkylation of amine), resulting in reduction of the selectivity of N-butyl furfurylamine. After optimizing the reaction temperature, the effect of reaction pressure on catalytic performance of furfural reducing amination over the Ni2P@C-700 catalyst was also evaluated (Fig. 8b). With the increase of reaction pressure from 0.6 to 1.4 MPa, the selectivity of N-butyl furfurylamine increased, it indicated the conversion of N-butyl furfurylimine to N-butyl furfurylamine was accelerated by the higher reaction pressure. The selectivity did not change significantly when the pressure increased further. The maximum yield of N-butyl furfurylamine reached 85.7 % under optimized reaction pressure was 1.4 MPa. The effect of reaction time on the catalytic performance of Ni2P@C-700 catalyst was studied(Fig. 8c). The selectivity of N-butyl furfurylamine increased firstly and then stabilized with the extension of reaction time. It is worth noting that the selectivity of N-butyl furfurylimine was decreased with increasing the selectivity of N-butyl furfurylamine, it means that N-butyl furfurylimine was hydrogenated to form N-butyl furfurylamine in the reaction process [65]. The selectivity of N-butyl furfurylamine reached the maximum of 85.6 % when the reaction was carried for 2.0 h. When the reaction time was prolonged from 2.0 to 6.0 h, the selectivity of N-butyl furfurylamine was remained at about 85.6 %. Under the conditions of reaction temperature of 170 ºC, reaction pressure of 1.4 MPa and reaction time of 2.0 h by using methanol as a solvent, the dosage of the Ni2P@C-700 catalyst was also optimized (Fig. 8d). The selectivity of N-butyl furfurylamine increased with raising the amount of catalyst. When the dosage of catalyst was 40 mg, the yield of N-butyl furfurylamine reached 85.0 %, and the yield of the target product did not increase significantly with increasing the dosage of Ni2P@C-700 to 50 mg. So, 40 mg was selected as the optimized dosage of Ni2P@C-700 catalyst for the reductive amination of furfural. In the literatures, nickel-based catalysts have been used in the reductive amination of furfural (Table S3). 12.5 % Ni/MMT was used as a catalyst, the selective of furfurylamine was achieved 85 % with the 96 % conversion of furfural, but the reaction time was prolonged to 7 h. The middle selectivity was obtained in the presence of Ni/SiO2 when the reaction was performed for 10 h. Prolonging the reaction time to 60 h, the 81.8 % selectivity with 86.6 % conversion was shown with employing Raney Ni as a catalyst. The 92.3 % selectivity was displayed with using Si/PNc as a catalyst, but the 3.0 MPa reaction pressure was required. Comparing with the listed catalysts in Table S3, the selectivity of furfurylamine reached 85 % under the mild conditions and the low catalyst dosage by using Ni2P@C-700 as a catalyst. Therefore, comparing with the reported nickel-based catalysts, Ni2P@C-700 catalyst showed the better catalytic performance in the reductive amination of furfural. Probable reaction pathways Based on the experimental results and literatures [27,66–68], the possible reaction pathways over the Ni2P@C-T catalysts were proposed and shown in Scheme 1 . Firstly, N-butyl furfurylimine (2) was generated from furfural (1) and butylamine by the condensation, the acidic sites on the surface of Ni2P@C-T facilitated the condensation of furfural and butylamine to quickly generate N-butyl furfurylimine (2). And then, the N-butyl furfurylimine (2) was hydrogenated to form N-butyl furfurylamine (3). In this processes, surface acidic sites of Ni2P@C-T was beneficial to accelerate the hydrogenation of N-butyl furfurylimine (3), due to the activation of C=N bonds through the interaction between the acidic sites and N atoms of corresponding C=N bonds [62]. As the active sites for hydrognation, the Niδ+ on the surface of Ni2P@C-T catalyst provided the active hydrogen species for hydrogenation of N-butyl furfurylimine (2), owning to the adsorption and activation of hydrogen on the catalyst surface [23]. Therefore, it was reasonable that the synergistic effect of the active Niδ+ sites and acidic sites in the Ni2P@C-T catalyst played a critical role in hydrogenation of the in situ formed N-butyl furfurylimine (3). Moreover, N-butyl tetrahydrofuranylamine (4) as by-product was generated from the over-hydrogenation of the furan ring on N-butyl furfurylamine. On the other hand, the direct catalytic hydrogenation of furfural to form furfuryl alcohol (5) was also proceeded. Interestingly, N-butyl bisfurfurylamine (6) was also formed as other by-product in the reductive amination of furfural. It was believed that N-butyl bisfurfurylamine (6) was generated from the coupling reaction of furfuryl alcohol (5) and N-butyl furfurylamine(3), and this results means that Ni2P@C-T might serve as a catalyst for directed amination of alcohol. Recyclability study The stability of heterogeneous catalyst is one of the important parameters to evaluate its performance and application potential. Under the optimal reaction conditions, the stability of Ni2P@C-700 catalyst was investigated (Fig. 9 ). It can be seen that the furfural conversion remained 100 %, but the selectivity of N-butyl furfurylamine was decreased after six cycles of use. In order to explain the deactivation cause, the spent Ni2P@C-700 catalyst after seven cycles was characterized by XRD (Fig. 10 a). Comparing with the fresh Ni2P@C-700 catalyst, XRD pattern of spent Ni2P@C-700 catalyst not only showed the diffraction peaks of Ni2P but also shown the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 38.4°, 47.9 ° and 48.9 °, which were attributed to Ni12P5 (PDF#74–1381). These results implied that the crystal phase of nickel phosphide underwent a transformation during the reaction process and Ni2P with the highly catalytic activity changed to Ni12P5 with the low hydrogenation capacity due to the loss of phosphorus. XPS results of the spent Ni2P@C-700 catalyst showed the lower banding energy of Ni 2p 3/2 of the Niδ+ than that of the fresh catalyst, it was possibly to related to the loss of phosphorus, which weakened the electron transfer of nickel to phosphorus; on the other hand, the peak area ratio of Niδ+ to Ni2+ in the spent Ni2P@C-700 catalyst XPS was reduced comparing with that of the fresh catalyst, suggesting the content of active center Niδ+ was decreased (Fig. S4). TG analysis was also used to characterize the spent Ni2P@C-700 catalyst (Fig. 10b), the TG curve of the spent Ni2P@C-700 catalyst showed obvious weight loss (about 12 %) between 300–500 °C comparing with the fresh catalyst, which suggested the adsorption of amino compounds onto the surfaces of catalyst caused the decrease of its activity [69]. The weight gain for both fresh and spent catalysts was observed when they were treated at above 500 °C, which was due to the oxidation of Ni2P to NiO and P2O5 [70]. In order to observe the particle size change of the catalyst after seven cycles, the spent Ni2P@C-700 catalyst was analyzed by TEM and the results were listed in Fig. 11 . Comparing with the fresh catalyst, the particle distribution of Ni2P in the spent Ni2P@C-700 catalyst didn't exhibit the obvious agglomeration and its particle size remained at about 40 nm, suggesting the presence of carbon layer inhibited the particle growth of Ni2P. However, the 0.185 nm crystal face spacing was founded in the HRTEM images of the spent Ni2P@C-700 catalyst, which was corresponded to the (312) crystal face of Ni12P5, and this result was consisted with that of XRD. Conclusion In summary, a series of in situ carbon-encapsulated Ni2P@C-T catalysts were successfully synthesized by temperature programmed reduction method using phytic acid as phosphorus source. The crystal size, exposed crystal plane and the acidity, as well as the carbon layer coated on the surface of Ni2P in the Ni2P@C-T catalyst can be effectively controlled by changing the reduction temperature of precursor. The carbon layer in the Ni2P@C-T protected the active sites Niδ+ from oxidation, as a result of this, the content of Niδ+ species was increased. The Ni2P@C-700 catalyst with appropriate acidity and maximum content of Niδ+ species displayed the excellent catalytic performance in the reductive amination of furfurfal for selectively producing N-butyl furfurylamine under optimized reaction conditions. The highest selectivity of 85.0 % to N-butyl furfurylamine was obtained over the Ni2P@C-700 catalyst at 100 % conversion of furfural, and the catalyst maintained high catalytic activity and selectivity after 6 cycles. Therefore, this catalyst has a wide application prospect in the generation of nitrogen-containing fine chemicals from biomass platform molecules by reductive amination reaction. coredata.dc:description: The development of efficient non-noble metal catalysts for synthesizing amine derived from furfural has attracted attentions. Herein, a series of carbon-encapsulated nickel phosphide catalysts Ni2P@C-T were prepared using a facile pyrolysis strategy at different reduction temperatures by employing phytic acid as phosphorus and carbon source. The effects of reduction temperature on the particle size, exposed crystal faces and electronic property, as well as the catalytic performance of the Ni2P@C-T in the reductive amination of furfural were investigated. Higher Niδ+ content and appropriate acidity were beneficial to improve the catalytic performance of Ni2P@C-T, the selectivity of N-butyl furfurylamine over the Ni2P@C-700 catalyst reached 85.0 % at the furfural conversion of 100 % under optimal reaction conditions of 170 °C, 1.4 MPa H2 and 2 h. The stability experiment showed that the Ni2P@C-700 catalyst maintained high catalytic activity and selectivity after 6 cycles.
coredata.dc:title: In-situ carbon-encapsulated Ni2P@C catalysts for reductive amination of furfural
